    Lab1

    Lab1.Rmd
    library(SemesterProject7709)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

    **1. Download the Lab1_data.xlsx data file. This file contains fake data for a 2x3x2 repeated measures design, for 10 participants. The data is in wide format. Here is the link. https://github.com/CrumpLab/rstatsmethods/raw/master/vignettes/Stats2/Lab1_data.xlsx

    Your task is to convert the data to long format, and store the long-format data in a data.frame or tibble. Print out some of the long-form data in your lab1.Rmd, to show that you did make the appropriate conversion. For extra fun, show two different ways to solve the problem.

    If you need to modify the excel by hand to help you solve the problem that is OK, just make a note of it in your lab work.**

    ##Crump class method
library(readxl)
wide_data <- read_excel("~/Downloads/Lab1_data.xlsx", col_names = FALSE)
#> New names:
#> * `` -> ...1
#> * `` -> ...2
#> * `` -> ...3
#> * `` -> ...4
#> * `` -> ...5
#> * ...
library(tidyr)
#add missing labels on first and second row
wide_data[1, 3:7] <- 'Noisy'
wide_data[1, 9:13] <-'Quiet'
wide_data[2, 3] = 'Morning'
wide_data[2, 9] = 'Morning'
wide_data[2, 5] = 'Afternoon'
wide_data[2, 11] = 'Afternoon'
wide_data[2, 7] = 'Evening'
wide_data[2, 13] = 'Evening'
#use for loops to construct concatenated column names
one_row_header <- c(2:13)
for(i in 2:13){
  one_row_header[i]<-paste(wide_data[1,i],wide_data[2,i],wide_data[3,i], sep="_")}
replace(one_row_header,1,"Participant")
#>  [1] "Participant"       "Noisy_Morning_A"   "Noisy_Morning_B"  
#>  [4] "Noisy_Afternoon_A" "Noisy_Afternoon_B" "Noisy_Evening_A"  
#>  [7] "Noisy_Evening_B"   "Quiet_Morning_A"   "Quiet_Morning_B"  
#> [10] "Quiet_Afternoon_A" "Quiet_Afternoon_B" "Quiet_Evening_A"  
#> [13] "Quiet_Evening_B"
##Use concatenated column names
wide_data2 <- read_xlsx("~/Downloads/Lab1_data.xlsx", skip = 2)
#> New names:
#> * A -> A...2
#> * B -> B...3
#> * A -> A...4
#> * B -> B...5
#> * A -> A...6
#> * ...
names(wide_data2)[1:13] <- one_row_header
names(wide_data2)[1] <- "Participant"
wide_data2
#> # A tibble: 10 × 13
#>    Participant Noisy_Morning_A Noisy_Morning_B Noisy_Afternoon… Noisy_Afternoon…
#>          <dbl>           <dbl>           <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl>
#>  1           1              61              77               97               97
#>  2           2             100              68               92               57
#>  3           3              70              56               89               78
#>  4           4             100              84               59               85
#>  5           5              93              62               83               53
#>  6           6              70              72               72               99
#>  7           7              85              86               69               67
#>  8           8              51              78               69               59
#>  9           9              70              85               93               87
#> 10          10              50              81               96               90
#> # … with 8 more variables: Noisy_Evening_A <dbl>, Noisy_Evening_B <dbl>,
#> #   Quiet_Morning_A <dbl>, Quiet_Morning_B <dbl>, Quiet_Afternoon_A <dbl>,
#> #   Quiet_Afternoon_B <dbl>, Quiet_Evening_A <dbl>, Quiet_Evening_B <dbl>
##Pivot time!
library(tidyr)
long_data <- wide_data2 %>% pivot_longer(
  cols = 2:13,
  names_to = c("Loudness","Time","Letter"),
  names_pattern = "(.*)_(.*)_(.*)",
  values_to = "DV"
)
long_data
#> # A tibble: 120 × 5
#>    Participant Loudness Time      Letter    DV
#>          <dbl> <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <dbl>
#>  1           1 Noisy    Morning   A         61
#>  2           1 Noisy    Morning   B         77
#>  3           1 Noisy    Afternoon A         97
#>  4           1 Noisy    Afternoon B         97
#>  5           1 Noisy    Evening   A         89
#>  6           1 Noisy    Evening   B         94
#>  7           1 Quiet    Morning   A         87
#>  8           1 Quiet    Morning   B         87
#>  9           1 Quiet    Afternoon A         65
#> 10           1 Quiet    Afternoon B         53
#> # … with 110 more rows
    ##Use melt method found here: https://rdatatable.gitlab.io/data.table/articles/datatable-reshape.html
library(data.table)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'data.table'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':
#> 
#>     between, first, last
DT.wide_data2 <- data.table(wide_data2)
DT.wide_data2 = melt(DT.wide_data2, id.vars = "Participant",
                measure.vars = c("Noisy_Morning_A", "Noisy_Morning_B", "Noisy_Afternoon_A", "Noisy_Afternoon_B", "Noisy_Evening_A", "Noisy_Evening_B", "Quiet_Morning_A", "Quiet_Morning_B", "Quiet_Afternoon_A", "Quiet_Afternoon_B", "Quiet_Evening_A", "Quiet_Evening_B"))
DT.wide_data2
#>      Participant        variable value
#>   1:           1 Noisy_Morning_A    61
#>   2:           2 Noisy_Morning_A   100
#>   3:           3 Noisy_Morning_A    70
#>   4:           4 Noisy_Morning_A   100
#>   5:           5 Noisy_Morning_A    93
#>  ---                                  
#> 116:           6 Quiet_Evening_B    60
#> 117:           7 Quiet_Evening_B    59
#> 118:           8 Quiet_Evening_B    83
#> 119:           9 Quiet_Evening_B    58
#> 120:          10 Quiet_Evening_B    72

    That melted for sure! But now we need to re-widen a little bit by parsing out our concatenated columns

    DT.wide_data2$Time <-rep(c("Morning","Afternoon","Evening"), each=20, 2)
DT.wide_data2$Loudness <-rep(c("Noisy","Quiet"), each=60)
DT.wide_data2$Letter <-rep(c("A","B"), each=10, 6)
#delete extraneous column
DT.wide_data2[,variable:=NULL]
#rename value and reorder to remain consistent with above
setnames(DT.wide_data2, "value", "DV")
setcolorder(DT.wide_data2, c("Participant", "Loudness", "Time", "Letter", "DV"))
DT.wide_data2
#>      Participant Loudness    Time Letter  DV
#>   1:           1    Noisy Morning      A  61
#>   2:           2    Noisy Morning      A 100
#>   3:           3    Noisy Morning      A  70
#>   4:           4    Noisy Morning      A 100
#>   5:           5    Noisy Morning      A  93
#>  ---                                        
#> 116:           6    Quiet Evening      B  60
#> 117:           7    Quiet Evening      B  59
#> 118:           8    Quiet Evening      B  83
#> 119:           9    Quiet Evening      B  58
#> 120:          10    Quiet Evening      B  72
